the nation's first-ranking school; such famous private

institutions in commerce, engineering, law, medicine and
education; as well as a host of less well known colleges.
Japan is currently in the midst of a boom in higher education.
The number of four-year universities has increased from 52
before the war to 226, second only to the number of universi¬
ties in the United States. The policy of the Japanese
Government is to have at least one university in each of
the nation's 46 prefectures. There are also some 267 gtwo-
year colleges giving technical and semi-professional courses
of study. The present number of university and college students
is seven times the prewar figure.
This great expansion in higher education has arisen in part
from keener competition for desirable jobs. The old, estab¬
lished universities are swamped with applicants seeking
admission, but limited facilities have forced them to
restrict admission to one out of every 10 applicants, and
in extreme cases, one out of every 40 or 50. Nevertheless,
enrolments are swollen—Keio, for example, has 24,000 students.
The pressure on the less well—known institutions is relatively
light, and the overall picture suggests that any student
determined to acquire a college education can get one.
The Japanese Government is firmly committed to the principle
